summary: This is a transcript of a voluntary interview conducted by DOJ OIG Special Agents with a Federal Bureau of Prisons (BOP) facilities manager at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. The interview is part of the OIG investigation into the death of inmate Jeffrey Epstein and the surrounding circumstances, focusing specifically on the failure of the MCC's camera system to record on August 9-10, 2019.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Deceased inmate at the MCC whose death by reported suicide is the subject of the OIG investigation. The interview focuses on the camera system failure during the time of his death.

events.title: Camera System Failure at MCC
events.description: The camera recording system at the MCC's Special Housing Unit (SHU) failed, with multiple hard drives going down, resulting in most cameras not recording. An electronic technician reportedly discovered the issue and was allegedly told to fix it the next day.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead in his cell at the MCC. The cause was reported as suicide by hanging.

events.title: OIG Interview of BOP Facilities Manager
events.description: The DOJ Office of the Inspector General conducts a voluntary, sworn interview with the MCC facilities manager regarding the camera system failure and circumstances surrounding Epstein's death.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC), New York, New York
SIS office at MCC (housing the camera system)
keyFacts: The camera recording system in the MCC's SHU was not working on August 9-10, 2019, during the time of Jeffrey Epstein's death. Only one camera in the SHU was reportedly recording.
The system failure was attributed to old, antiquated equipment where multiple hard drives failed. A camera replacement project had been initiated in 2018 but was not yet completed.
The facilities manager was on vacation during the incident and stated he was not notified about the camera failure at the time. He learned of it upon his return.

Access to the physical camera system was controlled by the SIS (Special Investigative Supervisor) office. Only certain personnel (Comtechs and possibly computer services) had the administrative rights to take cameras offline via the software.
The interview reveals institutional knowledge of the outdated camera system and chronic understaffing, with only one Comtech employed at the time of the incident.
